user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_generic_dev_dma_map:
```c
int metal_generic_dev_dma_map(struct metal_bus *bus,
			     struct metal_device *device,
			     uint32_t dir,
			     struct metal_sg *sg_in,
			     int nents_in,
			     struct metal_sg *sg_out)
{
	int i;
	(void)bus;
	(void)device;

	if (sg_out != sg_in)
		memcpy(sg_out, sg_in, nents_in*(sizeof(struct metal_sg)));
	for (i = 0; i < nents_in; i++) {
		if (dir == METAL_DMA_DEV_W) {
			metal_cache_flush(sg_out[i].virt, sg_out[i].len);
		}
		metal_cache_invalidate(sg_out[i].virt, sg_out[i].len);
	}

	return nents_in;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function metal_generic_dev_dma_map:
#define METAL_DMA_DEV_W 2
...
struct metal_sg {
	void *virt; /**< CPU virtual address */
	struct metal_io_region *io; /**< IO region */
	int len; /**< length */
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
suspicious_frags:
if (sg_out != sg_in)
	memcpy(sg_out, sg_in, nents_in*(sizeof(struct metal_sg)));
explanation: Other fragments in the function are not suspicious for unreachable-code concerns: the (void)bus; and (void)device; lines are intentionally present to suppress unused-parameter warnings and are executed (they are not conditional or dead code). The variable declarations (int i;) and the final return nents_in; are reachable and straightforward. There are no compile-time constant conditions, unconditional returns/branches before other statements, gotos, or labelled blocks in this function that would make any remaining statements unreachable. The only places that could represent dead/unreachable code at runtime depend on the values of inputs (sg_out vs sg_in, dir, and nents_in) — these are the fragments listed above and should be investigated to determine whether those branches/loops can in practice never be taken.
